Dear Ms. Aufdemberge:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
November 27, 2018. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It
should be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of
the MSA and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of
this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions.
Sincerely,

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the
following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months
after the staff member assumes his or her current
responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a written
evaluation shall be conducted each year.
Three of eight employees did not have a timely probationary or
annual performance evaluation.
(repeat violation)
R 400.12325 License recommendation.
(2) An agency shall document foster home license changes
in the foster home record and shall communicate the
changes immediately to the department in the manner
prescribed by the department.
Two of eight addendums to renewals or annuals identified
changes in age ranges or other criteria without evidence the
agency assessed the appropriateness of the change.
R 400.12404 Placement.
(7) An agency shall document, in the child's record, within 7
calendar days after placement, the information specified in R
400.12417(1) and all of the following information:
(a) – (i)
There was no client information sheet for one of eight
foster children.
4

R 400.12404 Placement.
(7) An agency shall document, in the child's record, within 7
calendar days after placement, the information specified in R
400.12417(1) and all of the following information:
(g) Documentation of the child's placement preparation.
For two of eight foster children, the client information sheet
indicating the child’s placement preparation was left blank.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child's
record before a change of placement occurs:
(a) – (j)
Two of eight foster child records were not in compliance.
One child replaced on 7/9/18 had no DHHS-69b
documenting the change of placement.
For another child replaced, the change was documented on
the DHHS 69. Replacements are to be documented on the
DHHS 69b and the items on that form are consistent with
the licensing rules.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(d) Current immunizations for each child as required by
section 5111 of 1978 PA 368, MCL 333.5111.
Immunizations are not current for two of eight foster
children.
(repeat violation)
5

R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any treatment
required for each child who is 4 years of age and older,
including both of the following:
(i) A dental examination within 12 months before
placement or a new dental examination shall be completed not
more than 90 calendar days after placement.
One of eight new dental exams was completed 19 days
beyond the 90-day mark.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
Two of two initial service plans were completed 7 & 13 days
late.
(repeat violation)
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Two of 23 updated service plans were completed 10 & 22
days late.
(repeat violation)
6

R 400.12505 Supervision.
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum supervision:
(a) Face-to-face contact between the social service worker
and the youth in independent living at least once each month at
a youth's place of residence.
For one of four IL youth, the IL worker did not visit the
youth for four months at the youth’s place of residence.
(repeat violation)
R 400.12505 Supervision.
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum supervision:
(b) At monthly intervals, ensure that the youth is complying
with the terms of the contract required by R 400.125010,
continues to reside in a safe and acceptable environment, and
is managing expenditures.
For one of four IL youth, a budget was not completed
during one month.
(repeat violation)
R 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record shall contain all of the following information

once every 90 calendar days:

(i) Name.
(ii) Social security number.
(iii) Address and telephone number.
(iv) Date of birth.
(v) Gender
(vi) Race.
(vii) Height.

(viii) Weight.

R 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record shall contain all of the following information
and documentation, which shall be recorded within 30 calendar
days after placement in independent living and updated at least
once every 90 calendar days:
(o) Service plans as required in R 400.12419 and R
400.12420. If the youth has biological children, the service plan
must address the living arrangement for the child or children,
visitation/parenting time with the youth's biological children or a
clear explanation why this is not possible or appropriate.
Three of three ISPs for IL youth were 1, 22 & 23 days late.
Four of five USPs for IL youth were 2, 2, 5 & 8 days late.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. The facility is in compliance
will all additional MSA requirements except for the following:

(repeat violation)
ISEP 6.33 – Children over 14 must sign their PATP
Three of three service plans were not signed by a foster child over 14.

ISEP 6.18 pg 23 – Relative foster parent applicants shall be licensed within 180
days of the date of application
Six of 11 applicants were not licensed within 180 days
(repeat violation)
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that there
are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in section
1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements
except for the following:
FOM 801 – Medical passports are to be provided to foster parents
One passport for eight children was not provided/signed by the foster parent.
(repeat non-compliance)
FOM 801 - DHHS 1643 Psychotropic medication consents must be completed on
the DHHS 1643
One consent form for eight children was completed, but not on the DHHS- 1643.
FOM 722- 6B – FTMs are to be held quarterly
One of eight foster children did not have one FTM during one quarter.
FOM 722-08C – Caregiver signatures on PATPs
7 of 25 PATPs were not signed by the foster parent.
(repeat non-compliance)
FOM 722-6I – Sibling visits for split sibs must occur monthly
9

Two of seven required sibling visits did not occur for one foster child.
(repeat non-compliance)
FOM 722- 06H – One unannounced foster home visit per quarter
Four of 25 required unannounced home visits were announced.
(repeat non-compliance)
FOM 722-09C – DHHS-69b is to be completed when an IL youth moves from one
home to another
One of four IL youths moved from the community to Shephard hall and no DHHS 69b was
completed.
ADM 710 - Children shall be registered on MARE within 30 days
Two of four children were not registered on MARE within 30 days of case acceptance.
ADM 300- Child assessments must be completed within 45 days of case
acceptance
One of four assessments was not completed within 45 days.
ADM 330- Quarterly reports are to be timely
Five quarterlies were late for two of four children.
4 months, 5 weeks, 3 weeks, 3 days and 1 day late
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
Foster Care
 Pediatric checklists should be signed and dated by foster care worker
 All items on the ASQ and Pediatric checklist should be filled out, the pages
kept together and uploaded
 For new school enrollments, the new school name and enrollment date should be
documented separately outside of social work contacts, correctly labelled and
uploaded so the information can be found during audits.
10

Licensing
 DHHS workers (foster care, POS, CPS, MIC) should not be misidentified as
the “DHHS consultant” in any reports.
 To assure the agency has kept up with foster home changes, update and
identify the foster child’s current routine day care situation in Renewals and
Annuals. Include the day care provider’s name and license number
ANALYST CONCERNS & RESOLUTIONS
Safety Alert 1
Concern: Foster parent reported not receiving medical passports for foster children.
Resolution: Six medical passports were required for two children in March, June and
September 2018. Four medical passports were not provided to the foster parent.
(Policy non-compliance cited above) The foster parent was provided updated medical
passports for both children at the November home visit on 11/29/18.
Safety Alert 2
Concern: Foster parent reported not receiving medical passports for foster children.
Resolution: One medical passport was required for one child. That medical passport
was provided to and signed by the foster parent in a timely manner. The foster parent
was provided and signed updated medical passports on 9/10/18, 10/14/18 and
11/04/18.
Concern: Foster parent did not receive a clothing order.
Resolution: The foster parent did not request a clothing order. The case worker did
submit for an initial clothing allowance on 09/13/18 in MISACWIS. The request was
made within 30 days of the initial placement in the foster home and it is pending
MDHHS approval.
Safety Alert 3
Concern: Sleeping arrangements do not meet licensing requirements. One grandchild
sleeps on the couch another grandchild sleeps on the floor in the foster parent’s room.
Resolution: The foster parent does allow her grandson (17) to sleep on a couch and
her granddaughter (11) to sleep in her room on an air mattress. The foster parent’s
relatives for whom she became licensed are no longer in care. A request was made to
DCWL on 05/01/18 to close the license for failure to renew. DCWL indicated on
11/30/18 that the closure was effective on that day.

V. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MSA requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
